User Story: As a user, I want to create a new world with basic information so I can start building my narrative setting.
Acceptance Criteria:
The WorldCreationWizard guides the user through steps including providing a freeform description
Basic validation ensures required fields (name, description) are filled
Created worlds are saved to the system with unique identifiers
The user can navigate between wizard steps with appropriate validation
The creation process is intuitive and user-friendly
Technical Requirements: The system must guide users through the world creation process with clear steps. It must validate required fields, save created worlds with unique identifiers, and allow intuitive navigation between wizard steps with appropriate validation.
Implementation Considerations: Consider the balance between flexibility and guidance in the world creation process. Think about what information is essential to collect upfront versus what can be configured later. The creation flow should feel approachable to new users while allowing for depth of customization.

User Story: As a user, I want clear step-by-step guidance during world creation so I don't miss important configuration options.
Acceptance Criteria:
The wizard clearly indicates the current step and total steps
Each step has a clear title and description of what needs to be configured
The wizard prevents advancing to the next step if required fields are incomplete
Progress is saved between steps to prevent data loss
Navigation between steps is intuitive and consistent
Technical Requirements: The system must clearly indicate current step and total steps in the creation process. Each step must have a clear title and description. The system must validate required fields before allowing advancement and save progress between steps. Navigation between steps must be intuitive and consistent.
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to communicate progress effectively without overwhelming users. Think about validation timing that feels helpful rather than restrictive. The step-by-step guidance should strike a balance between thoroughness and maintaining user momentum through the process.

User Story: As a user, I want suggestions and help text for each field so I understand what I'm configuring.
Acceptance Criteria:
The UI displays AI-generated suggestions for attributes and skills based on the description
Tooltips or help text are available for key configuration fields
Example values are shown where appropriate
Error messages provide guidance for resolving validation issues
Help content is context-sensitive and relevant
Technical Requirements: The system must provide context-appropriate suggestions and help text for configuration fields. It must show example values where appropriate, display guidance for resolving validation issues, and ensure help content is relevant to the current context.
Implementation Considerations: Consider the appropriate level of detail for help text that informs without overwhelming users. Think about when AI-generated suggestions would be most valuable in the creation process. The help system should reduce user uncertainty while encouraging creative world-building.

User Story: As a user, I want to add custom attributes to my world so I can define character traits.
Acceptance Criteria:
The AttributeEditor component allows adding new attributes (up to 6 total)
Users can define attribute name and description
The interface prevents creating duplicate attribute names
Added attributes appear immediately in the attributes list
The interface is intuitive and easy to use
Technical Requirements: The system must allow users to add custom attributes with name and description (up to a reasonable limit). It must prevent duplicate attribute names, provide immediate feedback when attributes are added, and offer an intuitive interface for attribute management.
Implementation Considerations: Consider what guidance will help users create meaningful attributes without overly restricting their creativity. Think about how to communicate system limitations like the maximum number of attributes in a user-friendly way. The attribute creation interface should balance flexibility with structure.

User Story: As a user, I want to set attribute ranges and default values so I can establish world norms.
Acceptance Criteria:
Users can set a default value for each attribute within the allowed range
Min/Max values are fixed at 1-10 for MVP
The interface provides visual controls for setting numeric values
Invalid values are prevented through UI constraints
Value adjustments provide immediate visual feedback
Technical Requirements: The system must allow users to set default values for attributes within defined ranges. It must provide visual controls for setting numeric values, prevent invalid values through UI constraints, and provide immediate visual feedback for value adjustments.
Implementation Considerations: Consider what visual controls best communicate numeric value selection while being intuitive to use. Think about how to explain the significance of default values in establishing world norms. The value configuration should help users create balanced and internally consistent worlds.

User Story: As a user, I want to edit attributes after creation so I can refine my world.
Acceptance Criteria:
Existing attributes can be edited or removed via the interface
Edits to attributes are saved immediately
The system warns when removing attributes that are linked to skills
Attribute changes are reflected in the world configuration
The editing interface is consistent with the creation interface
Technical Requirements: The system must allow editing and removing existing attributes. Edits must be saved immediately. The system must warn users when removing attributes linked to skills and reflect attribute changes throughout the world configuration. The editing interface must be consistent with the creation interface.
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to handle cascading effects when attributes are modified or removed. Think about what warnings or confirmations would be helpful without being overly intrusive. The editing experience should encourage refinement while preventing accidental breaking changes.

User Story: As a user, I want to create skills linked to attributes so characters can have specialized abilities.
Acceptance Criteria:
The SkillEditor component allows adding new skills (up to 12 total)
Users can define skill name and description
The interface prevents creating duplicate skill names
Added skills appear immediately in the skills list
Skills can be linked to one or more attributes
Technical Requirements: The system must allow users to create skills with names and descriptions (up to a reasonable limit). Skills must be linkable to one or more attributes. The system must prevent duplicate skill names and provide immediate feedback when skills are added.
Implementation Considerations: Consider the relationship model between skills and attributes that provides flexibility while maintaining logical connections. Think about how to visually represent these relationships in the interface. The skill creation system should guide users toward creating character abilities that feel natural within their world context.

User Story: As a user, I want to define skill ranges and default values so I can control skill distribution.
Acceptance Criteria:
Users can set a default value for each skill within the allowed range
Min/Max values are fixed at 1-5 for MVP
The interface provides visual controls for setting numeric values
Invalid values are prevented through UI constraints
Value adjustments provide immediate visual feedback
Technical Requirements: The system must allow users to set default values for skills within defined ranges. It must provide intuitive visual controls for setting numeric values, prevent invalid values, and provide immediate visual feedback for value adjustments.
Implementation Considerations: Consider how the skill value scale relates to and differs from the attribute scale in meaning and impact. Think about how to communicate the significance of default skill values in the game system. The value configuration should help users create balanced skill distributions appropriate for their world.

User Story: As a user, I want to organize skills by related attributes so there's logical character development.
Acceptance Criteria:
Users can link each skill to 1-2 existing attributes via a selection mechanism
The UI shows which attributes are linked to each skill
Skills maintain their attribute relationships after editing
The system validates that linked attributes exist
The relationship between skills and attributes is clearly visualized
Technical Requirements: The system must provide a mechanism to link skills to relevant attributes. It must clearly display these relationships in the interface, maintain them during editing operations, validate relationship integrity, and clearly visualize the connections between skills and attributes.
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to visually represent the relationship between skills and attributes in an intuitive way. Think about what constraints on these relationships make sense for game balance. The organization system should help users create coherent character progression paths within their world.

User Story: As a user, I want to view all my created worlds so I can select one for play.
Acceptance Criteria:
The WorldList component displays all created worlds
Worlds can be selected for viewing or play
The world list loads automatically when the page is accessed
The list is responsive and works on different screen sizes
The list provides clear visual differentiation between worlds
Technical Requirements: The system must display all created worlds in a list view. It must allow users to select worlds for viewing or play. The list must load automatically when accessed, be responsive across different screen sizes, and provide clear visual differentiation between worlds.
Implementation Considerations: Consider what information about each world is most important for users when selecting worlds from a list. Think about visual approaches that help users quickly identify and distinguish between their worlds. The list view should balance information density with clarity and ease of selection.

User Story: As a user, I want to see basic information about each world so I can identify them easily.
Acceptance Criteria:
Each world entry displays name, description, and genre
The list shows when each world was created or last modified
The information is presented in a clean, readable format
The display adapts responsively to different screen sizes
Important information is visually emphasized
Technical Requirements: The system must display key information for each world including name, description, genre, and timestamps. This information must be presented in a clean, readable format that adapts to different screen sizes with visual emphasis on important details.
Implementation Considerations: Consider what information hierarchy best helps users identify and differentiate their worlds. Think about what aspects of world information deserve visual emphasis. The information display should help users quickly recognize and select the world they want to access.

User Story: As a user, I want to edit existing worlds so I can refine my settings.
Acceptance Criteria:
Selecting a world allows viewing/editing its details via the WorldEditor
The WorldEditor provides forms to modify basic info, attributes, and skills
Changes are saved automatically or with an explicit save action
The editor prevents invalid modifications
The editing interface is consistent with the creation interface
Technical Requirements: The system must allow users to edit existing world details including basic information, attributes, and skills. It must save changes appropriately, prevent invalid modifications, and provide an editing interface consistent with the creation experience.
Implementation Considerations: Consider the appropriate save behavior (automatic vs. explicit) based on the significance and frequency of changes. Think about what validation is necessary to maintain world consistency while allowing creative freedom. The editing experience should feel familiar to users who have completed the creation process.

User Story: As a user, I want to delete worlds I no longer need with proper confirmation.
Acceptance Criteria:
A delete option is available for each world
A confirmation dialog is shown before completing deletion
The world list updates immediately after deletion
The system provides feedback when deletion is complete
The confirmation dialog clearly explains the consequences of deletion
Technical Requirements: The system must provide the ability to delete worlds with appropriate confirmation safeguards. It must show a confirmation dialog that clearly explains deletion consequences, update the world list immediately after deletion, and provide feedback when the operation completes.
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to balance protecting users from accidental deletion while not making the process overly cumbersome. Think about what information should be included in confirmation messages to help users make informed decisions. The deletion process should be clear but not alarming or disruptive.
